Article Title: After 10-yr chase, wildlife sleuths nab the ‘ghost’
Article Text:
Woman Behind Massive Trafficking Network Finally Runs Out Of Luck In Snowbound Village On China Border

BHOPAL: In the snowbound silence of Lachung, in north Sikkim, 43-year-old wildlife trafficker Yangchen Lachungpa, wanted by Interpol, finally ran out of mountains.For 10 years, agencies across India and abroad had hunted for Yangchen — a woman who, investigators said, moved like a ghost, slipping across borders, abandoning safe houses hours ahead of raids, and allegedly built trafficking corridors that linked Madhya Pradesh’s tiger reserves to Nepal, Tibet and China.But on Dec 2, in a tiny Himalayan village just a few km from the India-China border, the chase ended in a way even veteran officers described as “like watching a film play out in real time”.As radios died and torches dimmed in the freezing darkness, the MP State Tiger Strike Force (STSF) and Wildlife Crime Control Bureau (WCCB) team found itself under jurisdiction of the Dzumsa, Lachung’s centuries-old self-governing council. Villagers reportedly blocked the only exit, and elected headmen demanded documents. And the officers — carrying warrants for one of the world’s most elusive wildlife traffickers — were forced to defend every procedural step before being allowed to detain Yangchen.At the centre of this standoff sat the woman they had chased for a decade — Yangchen Lachungpa, also the former wife of 44-year-old Jaiy Tamang, arrested from Delhi for his alleged role in smuggling pangolin scales.Tamang’s confession years earlier had first exposed Yangchen as a critical architect of the smuggling chain.Officers said Yangchen allegedly tried to destroy two cellphones and a coded diary containing names, routes and hawala references before the arrest could be completed. “It was part standoff, part village trial, part global crime bust. We had an Interpol fugitive sitting in front of us, but first, we had to convince a 400-year-old council that Indian law applied,” said an investigator.Her eventual arrest came only after months of technical surveillance, decoy movements and night-time encirclements across high-altitude terrain. The operation was monitored closely by Madhya Pradesh govt, officials said, given the seriousness of the tiger-poaching case.Yangchen’s arrest marks one of India’s most significant breakthroughs in wildlife enforcement — and one of the rare arrests executed following an Interpol Red Notice, issued on Oct 2, 2025, at India’s request. It allowed law enforcement in 195 countries to detain her if found.Originally from Tibet, Yangchen allegedly built trafficking corridors that funnelled tiger parts, pangolin scales, red sanders, shatoosh wool and Cordyceps to international buyers. She frequently moved between Delhi and remote Sikkim hideouts, often vanishing just before surveillance teams closed in.The role of this syndicate surfaced repeatedly in international seizures. In 2013, Nepal Police intercepted five tiger skins and seven sacks of bones en route to Tibet; DNA testing later matched one hide to Pench tigress T-13. In 2015, Ethiopian authorities confiscated eight tiger skins believed to have originated in central India. Both cases, investigators said, bore the hallmark of the alleged network Yangchen helped create.The case that finally cornered her began in July 2015, when MP authorities seized tiger bones, skin, pangolin scales and bone oil extract from Satpura Tiger Reserve. STSF uncovered what officials called a “highly structured multinational trafficking chain.” As many as 31 accused were arrested, and 27 were convicted by a Narmadapuram court in 2022. But Yangchen, the woman believed to be the missing link — the one connecting village-level poachers to buyers beyond the Himalayas — remained out of reach.She was arrested once in Sept 2017, but went on the run after obtaining interim bail. In 2019, her anticipatory bail was rejected, and she disappeared again, prompting authorities to seek international intervention.After her arrest in Lachung, Yangchen was transported to Gangtok for medical examination and produced in court on Dec 3, where MP authorities secured transit remand. Sikkim Police provided vital support in what officers called “one of the most culturally delicate and operationally dangerous extractions in recent memory”.Payments in the network were allegedly routed through Kathmandu, Siliguri and border villages, while suspected wildlife stockpiles were maintained in Satpura, Pench, Betul and Tamia forests. The coded diary recovered in the raid is expected to reveal financial backers, international contacts and the deeper structure of the trafficking chain.A senior enforcement officer said the breakthrough “finally gives sleuths a chance to expose the top tier of global wildlife contraband markets”, adding that more arrests across states — and potentially across borders — are likely.
Article Summary: Yangchen Lachungpa, 43, wanted by Interpol, finally ran out of mountains. She allegedly built trafficking corridors that linked Madhya Pradesh’s tiger reserves to Nepal, Tibet and China. She was also the former wife of 44-year-old Jaiy Tamang, arrested for smuggling pangolin scales.

Article Title: HC tells Bengal govt to pull out all stops ahead of ‘Babri’ event
Article Text:
Calcutta high court

Rajnath Singh Claims Nehru Wanted Babri Built With Public Funds But Sardar Patel Blocked His Plan

KOLKATA/BEHRAMPORE: Calcutta HC directed the Bengal govt Friday to do whatever it takes to pre-empt communal disturbance in Murshidabad’s Beldanga ahead of suspended TMC MLA Humayun Kabir ’s planned foundation-laying ceremony for a “Babri Masjid”, coinciding with the Dec 6 anniversary of the Ayodhya structure’s 1992 demolition.“The state must act per its stand... The law-and-order situation in Murshidabad shall be strictly maintained, and the lives and properties of citizens will be protected,” the division bench of acting Chief Justice Sujoy Paul and Justice Partha Sarathi Sen said while disposing of a PIL against the scheduled event.Kabir’s mosque plan comes barely eight months after communal violence in Murshidabad, triggered by protests against the Wakf (Amendment) Act, 2025.Advocate-general Kishore Datta told the bench the state had already deployed adequate forces to thwart any plan to disturb peace. Deputy solicitor-general Rajdeep Majumdar said 19 companies of CISF were stationed in the area. A 3,500-strong security contingent, including RAF units, fanned out into Rejinagar and its surrounding areas on the eve of the event. Two BSF companies are on standby to secure NH-12.MLA Kabir, suspended by TMC a day ago, was summoned to Rejinagar police station Friday evening and questioned for several hours, sources said.Earlier in the day, a defiant Kabir supervised arrangements for Saturday’s event and asked his team to arrange 30,000 packets of biryani for his guests. He met splinter groups of Jamiat Ulama-i-Hind and All Bengal Imam Muezzin Association.“The main programme will start at noon. The Quran will be read for two hours. There will be no speeches, no political representation, no party flags, and no political canards. I will be there with 2,000 volunteers. Everyone knows... this isn’t a new thing,” he told reporters.TMC spokesman Kunal Ghosh alleged a conspiracy hatched by TMC’s main rival to discredit the party as the state heads into an election year.(With inputs from PTI)
Article Summary: Calcutta HC directs Bengal govt to do whatever it takes to pre-empt communal disturbance in Murshidabad. TMC MLA Humayun Kabir ’s planned foundation-laying ceremony for a ‘Babri Masjid’ coinciding with the Dec 6 anniversary of the Ayodhya structure’s 1992 demolition.

Article Title: Quad calls for bringing perpetrators of terror incident near Red Fort to justice
Article Text:
.

Red Fort Blast Had A Bigger Plan: Faridabad Doctor’s January 26 Recces Raise Chilling Questions

The Quad grouping has called for bringing the perpetrators, organisers and financiers of last month's terror incident near Red Fort in Delhi to justice and urged all UN member states to cooperate on it.The Quad, which comprises India, the US, Australia and Japan, also unequivocally condemned terrorism in all its forms including cross-border terrorism.Fifteen people were killed and several others injured in the terror incident on November 10.Ways to expand cooperation to combat terrorism under the framework of the grouping was the central focus of a meeting of a two-day Quad Counter Terrorism Working Group meeting held this week in New Delhi."Quad partners unequivocally condemned terrorism in all its forms and manifestations, including cross-border terrorism," a joint statement said."They also expressed their condolences for the heinous terror incident on November 10 near the Red Fort in Delhi," it said.The Quad partners "called for the perpetrators, organizers, and financiers of this reprehensible act to be brought to justice and urged all UN Member States to cooperate in doing so", it added.In the meeting, the Quad member countries exchanged assessments on the terrorism threat landscape, including developments in the Indo-Pacific region."They discussed the full spectrum of counterterrorism cooperation and measures that could be used to address existing and emerging challenges," the statement said.The Quad underscored the importance of ensuring that the Indo-Pacific remains open and free from the threats of terrorism.The Quad also reaffirmed their commitment to strengthening cooperation in multilateral fora."They also emphasised the value of continued information sharing on terrorists, terrorist organisations, and their proxies," the statement said.
Article Summary: The Quad grouping has called for bringing the perpetrators, organisers and financiers of last month's terror incident near Red Fort in Delhi to justice. The Quad, which comprises India, the US, Australia and Japan, also unequivocally condemned terrorism in all its forms including cross-border terrorism.

Article Title: ‘Exclusive rights over temple rituals’, TN defends defying HC order in SC
Article Text:
TN defends defying HC order in SC

NEW DELHI: While continuing its defiance of orders from Madras HC allowing lighting of the ‘ Karthigai Deepam ’ atop Thiruparankundram hills, Tamil Nadu’s DMK govt on Friday requested Supreme Court for an early hearing on its appeal but got no such assurance from CJI Surya Kant.When a counsel mentioned TN’s appeal before a bench of CJI Kant and Justice Joymalya Bagchi, referring it to as an issue of “lighting of a lamp on a hilltop” and urging for an urgent hearing, the CJI said he would consider its listing as soon as possible. The state govt defended its action of not complying with the HC orders allowing the traditional lighting of ‘deepam’ at the stone lamp pillar on the Thirupparankundram hillock near Madurai on the ground that legally it had exclusive rights over rituals and customs of Uchi Pillayar temple.HC had allowed the ‘deepam’, saying it would not encroach the rights of the adjacent dargah. The order passed by a single-judge bench was upheld by a division bench.Appearing for a caveator, advocate P V Yogeswaran said that on the one hand, TN is repeatedly defying the HC’s orders, and on the other, it is “creating a drama” by filing an appeal in SC to dissuade HC from proceeding with the contempt proceedings initiated against authorities for blatant, brazen and deliberate defiance of HC’s orders.In its appeal in SC, the MK Stalin-led DMK govt said HC cannot use its “contempt jurisdiction” to question temple rituals and customs, which are within the exclusive domain of authorities under TN Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowment Act, 1959.The single-judge bench on Wednesday initiated contempt proceedings against officials after the ‘deepam’ was lit at the temple, not at the ‘deepathoon’ atop the hill, as directed by it on Dec 1. TN’s appeal against this order was dismissed by the division bench.The DMK govt in its appeal in SC said the temple’s management, including the area under ‘deepathoon’ was under its exclusive control, and that it had passed prohibitory orders to ensure safety of citizens and take care of possible law and order situations. “The impugned judgment (of HC) raises important questions regarding the limits of contempt jurisdiction, the autonomy of temple management under statutory schemes, the effect of prior civil decrees and writ precedents, and the interface between judicial orders and executive law and order measures,” it said.The appeal detailed the tussle between HC and authorities. HC’s single-judge bench at 6.05pm on Dec 3 ordered authorities to allow the petitioner to go to the hilltop to light the lamp, and around the same time, the district collector issued prohibitory orders under Section 163 of the BNSS (Section 144 of CrPC) prohibiting persons from climbing the hillock to prevent a law and order situation.The division bench, while dismissing the state’s appeal, had said the executive orders under Section 162 of the BNSS cannot override judicial directions, and noted apparent manipulation/timing of prohibitory orders. It said the appeal was a “well-designed act” to pre-empt contempt. It said the single-judge would decide whether the non-compliance of its orders was wilful.
Article Summary: Madras HC had allowed lighting of the ‘ Karthigai Deepam ’ atop Thiruparankundram hills. Tamil Nadu’s DMK govt on Friday requested Supreme Court for an early hearing. The state govt defended its action of not complying with the HC orders.

Article Title: Mumbai: After 8 years in jail, man acquitted in Pocso case over ‘scanty evidence’
Article Text:
Representative image

Prosecution failed to prove girl was under age of 18: Judge

MUMBAI: After spending eight years in jail on charges of sexually assaulting a 17-year-old intellectually disabled girl, a 56-year-old driver was recently acquitted by a special Pocso court.The prosecution failed to prove the “basic foundational facts” of the case, highlighting major inconsistencies regarding the girl’s age, her mental capacity, and a significant contradiction between her statements and the medical report. “To my mind, evidence adduced by the prosecution is scanty and not sufficient to prove the guilt of the accused beyond reasonable doubt. If it were so, to my mind, the accused is entitled to get the benefit of doubt,” Special Judge ND Khose said.Advocates Kalam Shaikh and Vaishali Sawant, who defended the accused, submitted that he was falsely implicated due to a past conflict between the girl’s family and him.“No documentary evidence is placed on record showing that the victim is abnormal. Medical evidence is also not supporting the case of the prosecution,” the advocates submitted.The FIR was lodged on Aug 24, 2017. The prosecution alleged that the incident occurred on Aug 23, 2017, between 8 pm and 8.30pm in a slum area.The mother of the girl claimed that while she was at the market and her sons were out, the accused, a neighbour, entered their house. The girl, allegedly a child of 17 years with “less understanding”, later told her mother that the accused had kissed her and established physical relations.The judge noted that the prosecution failed to provide “clinching, believable and authentic documentary evidence” to prove she was under 18. “To my mind, the (birth) certificate… cannot be said to be useful to the prosecution for several reasons... Not only that, from the certificate… it reveals that the names of the father and mother of the girl are not mentioned as mentioned in a report... As such, to my mind, it can be said that no plausible documentary evidence is placed on record by the prosecution to prove the exact age of the girl on the alleged date of the incident. ”The judge said while the FIR suggested the year of birth was 2000, the school certificate indicated 2002. While the prosecution attempted to prove the girl had an IQ of 36, the judge found this claim unproven.
Article Summary: Prosecution failed to prove girl was under age of 18: Judge ND Khose. The judge noted that the prosecution failed to provide “clinching, believable and authentic documentary evidence” to prove she was under 18. While the prosecution attempted to prove the girl had an IQ of 36, the judge found this claim unproven.

Article Title: Tragedy Strikes: 23 Lives Lost in Arpora Nightclub Fire, Inquiry Launched
Article Text:
23 killed in Goa's Arpora nightclub fire

PANAJI: In a tragic incident, 23 people, including tourists, died after a massive fire broke out at Birch by Romeo Lane nightclub in Arpora on Saturday at midnight. The state govt has ordered an inquiry into the incident.The incident took place at around 11:45 pm on Saturday.Chief Minister Pramod Sawant said that it is a very painful day for all of us in Goa. "A major fire incident at Arpora has taken the lives of 23 people," he said. "I am deeply grieved and offer my heartfelt condolences to all the bereaved families in this hour of unimaginable loss."Sawant visited the incident site and ordered an inquiry into this incident. "The inquiry will examine the exact cause of the fire and whether fire safety norms and building rules were followed," Sawant said. "Those found responsible will face the most stringent action under the law—any negligence will be dealt with firmly."
Article Summary: A massive fire broke out at Birch by Romeo Lane nightclub in Arpora on Saturday. The state govt has ordered an inquiry into the incident. Chief Minister Pramod Sawant said that it is a very painful day for all of us in Goa.

Article Title: 'No home can be razed sans due process'
Article Text:
Representative image

(Inputs from Krishna Chaudhary & Asif Ansari)

MEERUT: Stressing that "no home can be demolished without due process", a division bench of justices Ajit Kumar and Satyavir Singh of Allahabad HC stayed the demolition of 27 houses in Bareilly's Shahabad area in Prem Nagar, directing the civic authorities not to take any coercive action "until the competent authority passes a final order. "The bench disposed of the writ with clear directions -- "Each petitioner must file an individual reply within four weeks, and the competent authority (civic body) must decide the matter within two months by issuing a reasoned, speaking order after granting a personal hearing. Until then - or for three months, whichever is earlier - no demolition may take place. The order was to be communicated to Bareilly officials. " A copy of the order has been accessed by TOI.The case reached court after residents received notices on Oct 9, declaring their homes "illegal" and ordering them to raze their structures within 15 days. The petitioners argued Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC) collected taxes for years, contradicting its own claim on its legality.Although the HC issued its stay order on Nov 13, BMC officials said the order took some time to reach them via official channels."We were aware of it, but the formal copy takes time and hence no action took place," municipal commissioner Sanjeev Kumar Maurya told TOI on Saturday. The petitioners received the order on Dec 2, and the residents thereafter rushed with their requests to the civic authority to halt the exercise.In Oct, BMC issued notices to the residents stating that the 27 homes were built illegally on municipal land and warned them that FIRs and recovery of demolition costs may follow. The action came in the backdrop of Sept 26 violence near Islamia Grounds during protests over the 'I Love Muhammad' row, after which authorities launched crackdowns on alleged illegal structures and violations linked to local cleric Tauqeer Raza and his aides.
Article Summary: Allahabad HC stays demolition of 27 houses in Bareilly's Shahabad area in Prem Nagar. The case reached court after residents received notices on Oct 9, declaring their homes "illegal" The petitioners argued Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC) collected taxes for years.

Article Title: File ping-pong triggers Omar-LG spat over J&K civil services exam
Article Text:
LG Sinha and CM Abdullah (File photo)



'Maligning Hindu Way Of Life': PM Modi Calls Out Colonial Mindset Over 'Hindu Rate Of Growth' Label

SRINAGAR: A political face-off erupted Saturday over age relaxation for J&K’s civil services exam, with chief minister Omar Abdullah accusing LG Manoj Sinha of stalling a crucial file and the latter’s office firing back that “misleading” claims are being spread as the Dec 7 test looms.Abdullah said that uncertainty has gripped aspirants because of “Lok Bhavan’s delay in approving age relaxation, a provision granted multiple times in the past”, and urged J&K Public Service Commission (JKPSC) to postpone the combined competitive (preliminary) exam. He also cited travel chaos caused by ongoing airline disruptions.The row comes amid student protests seeking an increase in the age limit. J&K currently caps the age at 32 for open-category candidates and 37 for reserved categories. Aspirants said other states such as Uttarakhand and Haryana allow candidates up to 42 years, while UP, MP and Rajasthan set the limit at 40.With five days left for the exam, thousands of candidates remain caught between a stalled decision and the risk of missing what many call a once-in-a-year chance.The LG’s office said it received the age relaxation file on Dec 2 and returned it the same day with a query on whether it was “logistically possible” to alter eligibility criteria so close to the exam.“Despite lapse of four days Lok Bhavan did not receive any response. I fully sympathise with young aspirants,” the statement said, adding that social media posts on the issue were “misleading”.The LG’s office also underlined that JKPSC had published the exam advertisement on Aug 22 and notified Dec 7 as the exam date on Oct 6.NC spokesperson Tanvir Sadiq had earlier claimed the CM had already approved the age relaxation proposal and forwarded it to the LG on Dec 2. After the LG’s statement, Sadiq said there was “absolutely no reason for any further queries” if the file had already been cleared by the CM.Parties trained fire on both sides. “JKAS age relaxation issue is turning out yet another classical case of passing the buck at the cost of young aspirants,” Peoples Conference chief Sajad Lone said. Congress urged both LG and CM to resolve the standoff without further delay, while PDP president Mehbooba Mufti called it “passing of responsibility”.
Article Summary: The row comes amid student protests seeking an increase in the age limit. J&K currently caps the age at 32 for open-category candidates and 37 for reserved categories. Aspirants said other states such as Uttarakhand and Haryana allow candidates up to 42 years.

Article Title: Nothing wrong if Tamil Nadu becomes like Ayodhya, says state BJP chief
Article Text:
Nainar Nagendran (File photo)

CHENNAI: With the ‘deepam’ row heating up, DMK netas accused BJP of attempting to stir communal unrest in TN, prompting BJP state chief Nainar Nagenthran to retort that there was nothing wrong in Tirupparankundram (Madurai) becoming like Ayodhya After paying respects to BR Ambedkar on his death anniversary in Chennai Saturday, Nainar told reporters, “Ayodhya is in India, not in England or Europe. There is nothing wrong in Tirupparankundram becoming Ayodhya. We have heard the greatness of Ram Rajya and want to implement it here.” He was responding to DMK’s allegations that BJP was trying to use the deepam issue to create an Ayodhya-like situation in Tirupparankundram.Asked about the communal tension rising in Tirupparankundram due to BJP and some Hindu groups trying to light the Karthigai Deepam at a stone pillar near a dargah atop the hill, Nainar said “there is no chance of communal riots, because none of the Muslims have said a word against it.”DMK MP Kanimozhi responded to Nainar, saying, “Should TN change like Ayodhya? Like Ayodhya in Faizabad constituency, where the people made BJP suffer a crushing defeat in the last election?” Countering her, former Telangana governor Tamilisai Soundararajan said there was communal harmony in BJP-governed states, and hence people continued to vote for the party.
Article Summary: DMK netas accused BJP of attempting to stir communal unrest in TN. BJP state chief Nainar Nagenthran retort that there was nothing wrong in Tirupparankundram (Madurai) becoming like Ayodhya. He was responding to DMK’s allegations that BJP was trying to use the deepam issue to create anAyodhya-like situation.

Article Title: Govt backs Tezpur univ pro-VC pick, protests intensify
Article Text: TEZPUR: Students of Tezpur University in central Assam blocked the exit of Union higher education secretary Vineet Joshi’s convoy Saturday after a closed-door meeting on allegations against “absconding” vice chancellor Shambhu Nath Singh ended without any assurance of action, triggering fresh slogans demanding his resignation.Joshi said the education ministry was examining the allegations and had heard all stakeholders but made no comment on possible action against Singh, who has stayed away from the campus since Sept amid protests over alleged unauthorised construction, financial irregularities and questionable appointments.“Regarding the demand for an inquiry against the VC, the team from the education ministry said they will send a report to the President. On the role of Joya Chakraborty as pro-VC, they said a decision will be taken as the students, teachers and staff have been opposing her appointment,” teachers’ association president Prof Kusum Kumar Bania said.Anger escalated after the ministry team allegedly insisted on continuing Chakraborty as pro–VC. Chakraborty’s name was allegedly pushed by Singh during an online meeting of the central university’s board of management — a move students termed “illegal”.In a parallel development, senior faculty member Dhruba Kumar Bhattacharyya assumed charge as acting VC Thursday night under provisions of the Tezpur University Act, 1993, though the appointment still awaits ministry approval.The protest entered its 79th day Saturday, with students highlighting the university’s slide to 79th position in this year’s NIRF rankings. Sources said Joshi will hold another round of meetings Sunday at the governor’s house in Guwahati.
Article Summary: Students of Tezpur University in central Assam blocked the exit of Union higher education secretary Vineet Joshi’s convoy Saturday. A closed-door meeting on allegations against “absconding’ vice chancellor Shambhu Nath Singh ended without any assurance of action.

Article Title: Night shift bust: Bengaluru prison warder held for smuggling cigarettes in underwear
Article Text:
Rahul Patil

Top Bengaluru Jail Official Transferred, 2 Suspended After Viral Videos Spark Outrage

BENGALURU: City police arrested a warder with Bengaluru Central Prison on charges of attempting to smuggle cigarettes and a saturated absorbent paper — suspected to be used for packing drugs — into the barracks Friday night.A prison warder (or Prison officer/guard) is a law enforcement professional responsible for the custody, supervision, safety, and discipline of inmates within a correctional facility. The arrested warder is Rahul Patil, who worked as a warder in different prisons since 2018. He was transferred to Bengaluru Central Prison from Belagavi this June.Police said Patil came to his night shift around 6.50pm, and during the frisking by Karnataka State Industrial Security Force personnel at the entrance, the banned substances were found in his undergarment. Two packs of cigarettes (10 each in a pack) and 60 grams of saturated absorbent paper were found."Immediately, the matter was brought to the notice of the senior prison officials, and a case against Patil was registered at Parappana Agrahara police station. He was arrested immediately," a senior police officer said.For a week, prison officials strictly banned the sale of cigarettes and beedis, which were earlier sold at the prison canteen.Though the prison manual prohibits their sales, prison officials, on humanitarian grounds, were selling them to inmates. A group of inmates protested against the ban, demanding the resumption of sales.Patil is the second warder to be caught smuggling banned substances into the prison in three months. In Oct, warder Amar Praje was allegedly caught while trying to enter the prison with a mobile phone by hoodwinking the security personnel. Based on suspicion, he was stopped and frisked, revealing a mobile phone concealed in his undergarment.
Article Summary: Rahul Patil is the second warder to be caught smuggling banned substances into the prison in three months. In Oct, warder Amar Praje was allegedly caught while trying to enter the prison with a mobile phone by hoodwinking the security personnel.

Article Title: 23 killed in Goa's Arpora nightclub fire: How a cylinder blast sparked deadly blaze; staffers trapped inside died of suffocation
Article Text:
Goa: 23 Killed In Arpora Nightclub Fire; Cylinder Blast Suspected, CM Sawant Vows Strict Action

GOA: At least 25 people died and 50 were injured after a fire tore through a popular nightclub in North Goa’s Arpora village late on Saturday night, officials said.Most of the victims were staff members working at the venue.Goa’s police chief Alok Kumar told news agency PTI that the blaze was triggered by a cylinder blast inside Birch by Romeo Lane, a nightclub that opened last year and is located about 25km from the state capital, Panaji."A total of 25 people have died, including four confirmed tourists and 14 staff members, while the identities of seven are yet to be established. Six others are injured and undergoing treatment", Kumar said.Also read: 'Blow to Goa’s reputation': Arpora nightclub fire kills 25 at ‘Birch by Romeo Lane’; most victims trapped in basement Chief minister Pramod Sawant, who visited the site shortly after the fire was brought under control, said that while three people died of burn injuries, the remaining victims appeared to have succumbed to suffocation.He added that initial information suggested the club had not complied with fire safety norms.“We will take action against the club management and also against the officials who allowed it to operate despite flouting safety norms,” the chief minister said.“This is an unfortunate incident during the peak tourist season.”Earlier statements from local authorities suggested no tourists were harmed, but Sawant later said that “three to four tourists” were also among those killed.Local MLA Michael Lobo, who was also at the scene, told reporters that all the bodies had been sent to the Goa Medical College in Bambolim. He said firefighters and police teams worked through the night to recover the victims and secure the area.Also read: ‘Safety norms not followed’: 25 dead, 50 injured in Goa’s Arpora nightclub fire; top developments Lobo said the Calangute panchayat would issue notices to all nightclubs on Monday, asking them to furnish valid fire safety permissions. Licences of establishments found operating without the necessary clearances would be cancelled, he added.Authorities have ordered a detailed inquiry into the incident, and a fire safety audit of all clubs in the area is expected to begin shortly.Prime Minister Narendra Modi spoke to chief minister Pramod Sawant to enquire about the fire incident in Goa. PM Modi said that the fire mishap is "deeply saddening.""An ex gratia of Rs. 2 lakh from PMNRF will be given to the next of kin of each deceased in the mishap in Arpora, Goa. The injured would be given Rs. 50,000.""My thoughts are with all those who lost their loved ones. May the injured recover at the earliest. The state govt is providing all possible assistance to those affected," PM Modi said.
Article Summary: A fire broke out at a nightclub in North Goa's Arpora village late on Saturday night. At least 25 people died, including four confirmed tourists and 14 staff members, while the identities of seven are yet to be established. Chief minister Pramod Sawant said that initial information suggested the club had not complied with fire safety norms.

Article Title: 2km in 2 hours: Why traffic was tied into knots on Delhi-Gurgaon Expressway
Article Text: GURGAON: IndiGo fliers weren't the only ones stranded in airports across the country through Thursday. Commuters on Gurgaon-Delhi Expressway weren't any better off.A flurry of weddings in hotels and farmhouses off the expressway had turned the arterial stretch into a virtual parking lot, bringing traffic to a grinding halt. So severe was the snarl that it took commuters nearly two hours to traverse just 2km from the Ambience Mall-Sirhaul border to Rajokri in Delhi — an ordeal that rivalled the plight of air travellers stuck in terminals.The gridlock began around midnight as cars of wedding guests around a popular star hotel spilled onto service roads, blocking the main carriageway. With not a single traffic cop in sight — on either the Gurgaon or Delhi side — frustration mounted among those trapped in the jam.The situation was baffling given the capital's heightened security, just hours after Russian President Vladimir Putin had landed at IGI Airport for a high-profile visit.Calls to the traffic helpline proved futile for many."I left my office in Udyog Vihar at 9.45pm and the moment I turned onto the expressway, I saw a huge traffic on the Shankar Chowk flyover as well as surface road. While snarls in the city are not entirely new, such tailback at that hour was definitely unusual.There was bumper-to-bumper traffic. It moved at a snail's pace till the toll plaza, but literally came to a standstill after that. While there was some movement on the Rajokri flyover, commuters using the service lane towards Delhi were stranded at the same spot for long. They had no option but to switch off their engines and wait inside. Some simply moved out of their cars and started walking," recalled a commuter.The sense of helplessness was palpable. "Since there was not a single cop around, I dialled 112 multiple times. But the calls either went unanswered or simply did not connect. It took me almost 10 attempts to get through to the control room. After waiting for several minutes, a cop on the other side told me the traffic jam was due to a wedding at a luxury hotel nearby. Guests at the wedding had parked their vehicles on the main highway. It was complete chaos from the Delhi-Gurgaon border till this hotel, even around midnight," the commuter added.Police eventually promised action. "We will tow away the cars that are parked outside this hotel and impound them," a police officer assured the commuter.However, the hotel in question — The Umaro — denied responsibility. "There were several weddings that took place on Thursday night in the vicinity. These cars belonged to guests from other venues," a hotel official told TOI.The chaos was not confined to Thursday night. On Friday too, the expressway continued to crawl, with traffic moving at a glacial pace well into the night. Traffic officials in the city attributed the congestion to ongoing work by NHAI on the Delhi side.Satyapal Yadav, ACP (traffic, highways) in Gurgaon, said, "The snarls on Friday were mainly due to some ongoing work of NHAI on the Delhi side of the expressway. We received many calls from commuters, following which our senior officers were on their toes to clear the traffic. We even contacted the Dwarka traffic inspector and NHAI officials and requested them to not continue the work during peak traffic hours."The knock-on effects were felt within the city as well. "I was coming back from Delhi and found a traffic pileup near Udyog Vihar. This was mainly due to a change in the flow of traffic at multiple locations within this office hub," said Abhinav Sharma, an IT professional.Delhi traffic officials pointed to the sheer volume of vehicles and the ripple effect of even minor disruptions. "Often, it's obstructions like vehicle breakdowns that choke the stretch. Our teams are on the ground through the day and have been managing congestion manually at times. This is especially on internal roads near farmhouses, where weddings are scheduled," an official said.
Article Summary: A flurry of weddings in hotels and farmhouses off the expressway had turned the arterial stretch into a virtual parking lot. It took commuters nearly two hours to traverse just 2km from the Ambience Mall-Sirhaul border to Rajokri in Delhi.

Article Title: San Diego to pay $30 million to family of Black teen shot in the back by police officer
Article Text: The city of San Diego agreed to pay $30 million to the family of 16-year-old Konoa Wilson, who was fatally shot in the back by a police officer as he ran away from a shooting at Santa Fe station.The payout resolves a wrongful death lawsuit filed in June by Wilson’s family against the city, which claimed the officer acted with “racial violence”. The agreement was made as a business decision and not an admission of liability, according to city documents obtained by CBS 8.The settlement is among the largest in response to a police shooting in the United States. In 2021, the city of Minneapolis agreed to a $27million civil settlement for George Floyd’s family after he was killed when an officer kneeled on his neck for nine minutes. Floyd said he could not breathe during the May 2020 arrest, Guardian reported.On 28 January, Wilson was standing at the Santa Fe station when another teenager approached him with a gun and began shooting. Wilson ran away, passing by officer Daniel Gold in a corridor. Body-worn camera and surveillance footage released by police showed Gold pulling out his gun and shooting at Wilson’s back within seconds. Gold identified himself as a police officer only after opening fire.Wilson was pronounced dead at hospital 35 minutes later. Although officers found a firearm on Wilson while providing first aid, the civil lawsuit says he neither brandished a weapon nor threatened Gold at the time of the shooting. The lawsuit accused Gold of “racial violence” by shooting at a Black teenager who was running away.It alleges that due to Gold’s “furtherance of systemic racism”, his immediate perception of Wilson as a “Black person contributed to [Gold’s] decision to shoot [Wilson] without warning when [Wilson] appeared before him”, depriving the teen of “his life and liberty”.Nicholas Rowley, the attorney representing Wilson’s family, told the New York Times Wilson had carried a gun because he had been attacked by gangsters: “The reason why he had a gun is because he is half Black and there were kids, some new gangster kids in San Diego, who had jumped him a few times and hurt him so bad he was in a hospital,” Rowley told the Times. “He was afraid.”
Article Summary: Konoa Wilson, 16, was fatally shot in the back by a police officer as he ran away from a shooting at Santa Fe station. The payout resolves a wrongful death lawsuit filed in June by Wilson’s family against the city. The settlement is among the largest in response to a police shooting in the United States.

Article Title: Indigo fiasco: Airline chaos abates in Bengaluru, but baggage nightmare persists for passengers
Article Text:
Aviation Meltdown Escalates As IndiGo Cancels 400 Flights And Government Enforces Fare Controls

BENGALURU: The chaos at Kempegowda International Airport (KIA) may have eased Friday night, but for hundreds of stranded passengers, the ordeal continued. Even as IndiGo continued to cancel flights, passengers spent up to 10 agonising hours sifting through piles of abandoned baggage — some damaged, some missing — as assurances of refunds did little to alleviate the stress caused by a system that collapsed without warning.Dhanya Ravindhran, whose flight was cancelled, waited over eight hours for her baggage and camera gear needed for a shoot. "I kept asking the IndiGo staff, but they had no idea how to retrieve it. They simply said, ‘Madam, please wait' for hours," she said. "Finally, with the help of an airport staff member, I found a small opening near the conveyor tunnel and pulled out my luggage myself. There were heaps of bags dumped there — easily over 1,000," she told TOI.Similarly, Arif Khan, a software engineer travelling to Jaipur, found his suitcase damaged after a seven-hour wait. "My bag looked like it had been thrown around. The wheels were broken, and no staff member could explain what happened...This is the worst situation for IndiGo in the history of its operations."For 24-year-old student Anjana Ram, the long wait escalated into panic. "I had medications in my checked-in bag.I waited almost nine hours and pleaded with the staff to prioritise it, but they said they weren't able to track individual bags," she said. When her luggage finally arrived, the zipper had been split open. "Things were falling out. It was heartbreaking."UK-bound traveller Prakash Menon described the scene as "an ocean of abandoned bags". He added, "People were climbing over piles to find their luggage. There was no system, no announcements, no queue management. It was unbelievable for an international airport of this scale."Even as crowds diminished by evening, travellers said the airport must urgently improve baggage retrieval procedures to prevent a repeat of this week-long disruption. "Refunds don't fix the mental stress or the damaged luggage," Menon said. "The system clearly wasn't prepared for a crisis of this magnitude."Singer takes ordeal to social mediaFor Bengaluru-based singer Ananya Prakash, what should have been a short flight to Hyderabad turned into an ordeal she will never forget. Her flight was abruptly cancelled, leaving her and hundreds of others stranded with no clarity. "The airlines are least bothered about passengers," she said, standing amid a sea of confused travellers. "People have been waiting for hours. There's no space to even sit."Her checked-in baggage only added to the distress. At first, airline staff told her the bags would be delayed. Then the message changed: it could take two days to get them back."I had all my work equipment in that bag," she said. As the chaos grew, Prakash took to social media, pleading for answers and highlighting the airline's indifference.
Article Summary: Passengers spent up to 10 agonising hours sifting through piles of abandoned baggage. Travellers said the airport must urgently improve baggage retrieval procedures. "Refunds don't fix the mental stress or the damaged luggage," Prakash Menon said.

Article Title: Chernobyl shield damaged: Ukraine blames Russia for loss of confinement capability
Article Text:
Russia Launches 653-Drone Night Assault as Fastiv Rail Hub Burns and Ukraine Reports Major Damage





The international atomic energy agency (IAEA) has said the protective structure built to contain radioactive waste at the Chernobyl nuclear disaster site can no longer fully perform its safety functions after being damaged in a drone strike earlier this year.The new safe confinement (NSC) - the giant steel arch installed to cover the destroyed No 4 reactor - was “severely damaged” during a February 14 strike that sparked a fire and tore through protective cladding, the agency said in a statement on Friday. The IAEA noted the structure has “lost its primary safety functions, including the confinement capability.”Ukraine has accused Russia of carrying out the attack, an allegation the Kremlin has denied.IAEA director general Rafael Mariano Grossi said only “limited temporary repairs” have been made so far. “Timely and comprehensive restoration remains essential to prevent further degradation and ensure long-term nuclear safety,” he added, noting there was no permanent damage to the NSC’s load-bearing structures or monitoring systems. The agency said it would continue supporting Ukraine in efforts to restore full safety at the site.Chernobyl has repeatedly drawn international attention during the nearly four-year war, notably when Russian forces seized and occupied the plant area in early 2022 before withdrawing weeks later.The NSC, completed in 2019, is the world’s largest movable land structure and was designed to last 100 years, enabling long-term cleanup of the world’s worst nuclear accident. Built at a cost of €2.1 billion, it was funded by more than 45 donor nations through the Chernobyl Shelter Fund, which the European bank for reconstruction and development described as “the largest international collaboration ever in the field of nuclear safety. ”The original 1986 explosion at Chernobyl spread radioactive contamination across large parts of Ukraine, Belarus and Russia. More than 30 people were killed immediately, according to the IAEA and the world health organization, with elevated rates of cancer and birth defects persisting in exposed regions.
Article Summary: The new safe confinement (NSC) - the giant steel arch installed to cover the destroyed No 4 reactor - was “severely damaged” during a February 14 strike. The IAEA noted the structure has “lost its primary safety functions, including the confinement capability”

Article Title: Watch: CCTV catches UP cops ‘dumping body’ to avoid work; outrage on social media
Article Text:
Shocking CCTV footage revealed police officers dumping an unidentified body outside a shop in Meerut's Lohiyanagar area overnight

'Sab Jagah Pohchenge': Yogi Adityanath On What's Next After Ram Temple, 'Kashi-Mathura' Slogan

MEERUT: Shopkeepers in Meerut's Lohiyanagar area were horrified to find an unidentified young man's body lying on their doorstep on Friday morning. And after checking their CCTV footage, they were in for more shock. The footage showed a few cops, in the dead of night, quietly dropping the corpse in front of one of the shops.The clip soon surfaced on social media, triggering outrage among netizens with many citing "local police apathy towards common people".To address the outrage, Meerut SSP Dr Vipin Tada immediately suspended the L-Block outpost in-charge Jitendra Kumar and constable Rajesh, and terminated the services of home guard Rohtash."I have also instituted an internal inquiry under SP city Ayush Vikram Singh. The youth is still to be identified," Tada said.It is alleged that cops in Nauchanadi jurisdiction found the unidentified body in L-Block outpost area on Thursday night. To avoid being dragged into postmortem procedures, they allegedly "shifted" the body to another police jurisdiction and dumped it outside the stationery shop of Ronit Bainsla in Kazipur under Lohiyanagar thana around 1:40 am.Bainsla told TOI: "I saw the body right at the shutter of my stationery shop early morning. Other shopkeepers also assembled in the morning and we informed the police. Curious about what could've happened, some of them looked into the CCTV footage and there it was revealed that men in police uniform had dumped the body there."
Article Summary: Shocking CCTV footage revealed police officers dumping an unidentified body outside a shop in Meerut's Lohiyanagar area overnight. The footage showed a few cops, in the dead of night, quietly dropping the corpse in front of one of the shops. The clip soon surfaced on social media, triggering outrage among netizens.

Article Title: Indian-origin driver Satwinder Singh jailed for over 7 years in New Zealand on rape charges
Article Text: Satwinder Singh, an Indian-origin Uber driver in New Zealand, has been sentenced to seven years and two months' jail for a 2023 incident when he switched the GPS of his cab and diverted to a different route while molesting a teenage passenger. The NZ Herald reported that the teenager had booked a short ride from Speight’s Ale House to an address in Hamilton East, late at night.During the drive, Singh asked the teen if she was wearing underwear when her dress shifted. The teen resisted his advances and told him, “no, can you not?” and later, “get off me” but the driver continued the unwanted contact. He disconnected the GPS, giving the impression that the trip was successfully completed but the cameras saw his car. He locked the car doors, reached over and put the woman's seat in the recline position before kissing her and touching her breasts. He then climbed on top of her and raped her, which the victim described as “very rough and very hurtful”, the report said. The teen was eventually dropped off at a friend's home in a distressed condition.Singh later told the police that it was fabricated and all that happened in the car was consensual.He also said New Zealand women are "forward and promiscuous".As the judge gave the verdict, she said the incident had had a "significant" impact on the victim's life, eaving her fearful of being away from home and feeling that the outside world was now “unsafe and threatening”. She also lives with “an overwhelming rage inside of her”, intensified by the court process.Singh's counsel sought a hardship discount from the court arguing that he would face additional challenges in custody as he was a Sikh Indian who lived in New Zealand for only 11 years. “He, as you will see, is a follower of the Sikh religion, so prison would place a hardship on him as opposed to someone who was born and raised in New Zealand," the counsel said.The judge declined the request and said Singh had worked as an Uber driver, interacting widely with the New Zealand public and should not deserve any special discount in jail. Singh's counsel sought a suppression of his photograph claiming that a close relative of the Uber driver was suffering from mental health issues.
Article Summary: Satwinder Singh, an Indian-origin Uber driver in New Zealand, has been sentenced to seven years and two months' jail for a 2023 incident. He switched the GPS of his cab and diverted to a different route while molesting a teenage passenger. He locked the car doors, reached over and put the woman's seat in the recline position before kissing her and touching her breasts.

Article Title: HasanAbi slams Asmongold for “unrestrained racism” toward Ilhan Omar
Article Text:
Image Via Instagram

“pure unfiltered, unrestrained

racism

,”

“parasite,”

“shit holes”

“destroyed home”

HasanAbi challenges Asmongold’s rhetoric and debate avoidance





Hasan Piker, widely known as HasanAbi, has sharply criticized fellow Twitch streamer Asmongold after a recent viral rant in which Asmongold attacked Congresswoman Ilhan Omar and made sweeping comments about immigrants and Muslim communities. On his livestream, HasanAbi described the clip asaccusing Asmongold of pushing harmful stereotypes and misleading narratives about Somali and Muslim immigrants in the U.S. Hasan argued that Asmongold’s stance had little to do with actual policy debates and everything to do with prejudice against Omar’s identity, including her race, religion, and hijab.The controversy began when Asmongold labeled Ilhan Omar aimplied she should be deported despite being a U.S. citizen, and referenced isolated welfare fraud cases to generalize an entire population. He also dismissed Islamophobia as a made-up concept and referred to African countries aswhile claiming immigrants are prioritizing foreign issues over American concerns. HasanAbi responded by calling these claims not only racist but factually incorrect. He also mocked Asmongold’s own personal living setup, ahe refuses to repair, as ironic commentary on who is truly neglecting their own opportunities.During his stream, Hasan argued that Asmongold benefits from minimal pushback due to bot farms and coordinated efforts that drown out critical responses on platforms like Reddit and Twitter. According to Hasan, right-wing creators receive algorithmic and community shielding that prevents accountability, while left-leaning figures face harsher scrutiny and faster disciplinary action. He emphasized that Asmongold’s talking points rely on emotional outrage rather than facts, and extended a challenge for a debate, though he predicted Asmongold would refuse because his arguments would collapse under pressure.Hasan further noted that Ilhan Omar has championed progressive policies such as Medicare for All, free college, and supporting workers’ unions, topics he believes Asmongold deliberately ignores to instead attack her identity. The lack of policy criticism, Hasan said, exposes the real motivation behind the rant: bigotry packaged as political commentary.The exchange has fueled heated conversation across Twitch and social media, with supporters of both creators defending their viewpoints. Whether Asmongold responds directly remains uncertain, but Hasan’s comments make one thing clear: he believes unchecked hate speech online is dangerous and must be called out, especially when directed at public officials already facing threats and discrimination.Also Read: How valuable MrBeast’s Beast Industries has become and what it means for fans
Article Summary: Hasan Piker, widely known as HasanAbi, has sharply criticized fellow Twitch streamer Asmongold after a recent viral rant in which he attacked Congresswoman Ilhan Omar. Hasan argued that As Mongold’s stance had little to do with actual policy debates and everything to do. with prejudice against Omar's identity, including race, religion, and hijab.

Article Title: Explained: Why even a locked up Imran Khan may still be a threat for Asim Munir
Article Text:
Imran Khan and Asim Munir (R) (AI-generated image used for representation) Source: ChatGPT

Pak President Zardari Approves Asim Munir As The First Chief Of Defence Forces Amid Power Tensions

Why Imran Khan still remains a threat to Asim Munir





PTI without Imran: Still a major force





PTI was barred from contesting the 2024 general elections.

Dozens of PTI leaders were detained.

PTI-backed independents still won more seats than any other group.

Popularity that has not faded





A 2023 Gallup Pakistan survey showed 61% of Pakistanis had a “good opinion” of him -- the highest rating among all national leaders as reported by Dawn.

Arab News quoted analysts saying Khan remains "too politically relevant to sideline."

Televised appearances that trigger unrest





Nationwide protests

Arson and clashes

Attacks on military installations, including the Corps Commander’s residence in Lahore

Nationwide mobile shutdowns and troop deployment

Why Pak army cannot 'eliminate' Imran Khan





Key factors keeping Khan politically alive:





Victimhood narrative: Solitary confinement and restricted access cast him as a political prisoner, a powerful image in Pakistan’s grievance-driven politics.

Mobilisation without presence: PTI’s digital machinery enables mass mobilisation even without Khan physically present.

Diaspora and social media influence: Global PTI networks amplify every statement, intensifying scrutiny on Pakistan’s military.

High-risk optics: Every court appearance or televised moment risks sparking unrest.

The state vs sentiment





The jail sentence - not the silence





Constitutional shift and expanding military power





Munir's foreign outreach and US engagement





Imran's strength: Mobilisation without access





Why the military needs more than power









Is Imran Khan still a threat to Asim Munir ? The question looms over Pakistan ’s power structure. Former Prime Minister and cricketer-turned-politician Imran Khan, now over two years into imprisonment, remains a potent challenge to army chief Asim Munir — whose rapid ascent and consolidation of authority have made him Pakistan’s de facto ruler.With Munir now elevated as the Pakistan's first chief of defence forces, commanding the army, navy and air force, his institutional power is at its strongest — yet the confrontation with Khan, even from behind bars, continues to shadow that authority. The two have been locked in a prolonged, deeply personal confrontation.Despite being confined, Khan has transformed from a jailed political leader into a symbolic and political counterweight to Munir’s expanding military-political dominance.Far from fading, the rivalry between the two men has only sharpened. Munir commands the state; Khan commands sentiment. And as the events of the last two years show, sentiment can be far harder to control.Imran Khan's incarceration has fuelled a narrative of persecution and martyrdom among supporters. Long spells of isolation, restrictions on visits, and recurring allegations of mistreatment have strengthened this perception, with some analysts warning that these measures risk backfiring.Imtiaz Gul, executive director of the Center for Research and Security Studies (CRSS), told Al Jazeera: "The primary objective of blocking access and keeping Khan in solitary confinement is apparently meant to break him into (agreeing to) a compromise and neutralise the groundswell of anti-government sentiment.”Increasingly, barring visits to Khan is viewed not merely as a security decision, but as a political strategy that may harm the governing PML-N and reinforce Khan’s narrative of institutional overreach.Even without its leader on the ballot, PTI remains one of Pakistan's strongest political forces.PTI claims widespread rigging, accusing the government and military of manipulating the results, allegations echoed by several independent observers. The establishment denies all wrongdoing, but the perception of electoral injustice has only strengthened PTI’s street momentum.For perspective, Imran Khan’s PTI had won 151 seats in the 2018 elections, defeating Nawaz Sharif’s PML-N (81 seats) and PPP (54). That victory was hailed by PTI as "the end of an era," breaking the decades-long political monopoly of the PML-N, PPP and the military establishment.Despite his imprisonment, Khan remains Pakistan’s most popular political figure.This enduring popularity, even at a time of complete political inability, poses a direct challenge to Munir's authority.Even brief, controlled public appearances continue to spark major political reactions.During the May 2023 unrest, Imran Khan's court appearance -- after his dramatic arrest by paramilitary forces -- showed him flashing a victory sign. The televised images spread instantly and triggered:These scenes were unprecedented not only for their scale but because the anger erupted in Punjab, the heart of Pakistan's military recruitment and administrative base.More recently, when false rumours about Khan’s death spread, PTI supporters mobilised across Islamabad, Rawalpindi, and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, again forcing an immediate government response.A leader who provokes unrest without speaking remains difficult to contain.An analysis in The Diplomat warns that the army "cannot afford to eliminate" a leader with deep political roots in Punjab.Such an act, the report cautions, could "unleash one that the state may not survive."Khan is ethnically Pashtun but politically anchored in Punjab, with support stretching across Punjab, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, and the diaspora. His arrest in 2023 showed that anger against the military establishment now emerges in Punjab.Eliminating him would not neutralise his influence; it would likely create a "martyr" of unprecedented scale.Munir commands the state apparatus. Khan commands sentiment.And in Pakistan, sentiment has repeatedly proved more enduring than power.No prime minister has survived a confrontation with the military, but no army chief has faced a jailed leader with such widespread support and political resilience.Since August 2023, Khan has faced a series of corruption and security-related cases. In January 2025, he received a 14-year sentence in a land-graft case, a verdict his supporters claim was engineered to keep him out of politics.Khan’s public statements from jail fuel the perception of political persecution. He has directly accused Munir of "moral bankruptcy," and called him "mentally unstable man" claiming Pakistan's constitution and rule of law have collapsed under him: "I have been kept in complete solitary confinement, locked inside a cell with no contact with a single human being for four weeks… even the basic necessities guaranteed under the jail manual have been taken away from us. "His family members have echoed concerns about his treatment. His sister, after visiting him, said he told her they were subjecting him to "mental torture" and held Asim Munir responsible.The recent 27th amendment -- widely called a "constitutional coup" -- has entrenched military dominance further. Munir's elevation as chief of defence forces gives him command over all three services.Mahmood Khan Achakzai, head of Tehreek Tahafuz Ayeen-e-Pakistan, warned: "There is no constitution in Pakistan now. No judiciary. No social contract. They have made one man into a king above all."Months ago, Munir's increasing visibility included multiple meetings with Donald Trump. Munir even nominated Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize, crediting him with easing India–Pakistan high military tensions, a move driven by a desire for US recognition. Trump later referred to him as his "favourite field marshal."It is often assumed that political power requires physical presence. Imran's continuing influence disproves that assumption.His followers still speak of him not as a convicted convict, but as a leader wronged. The slogans, the sense of injustice, the personal stories -- all add up to mobilisation potential. And that potential doesn’t require Khan’s freedom; it only requires people’s belief.Statements from his family amplify this -- for instance, the anguish voiced by his son over not knowing whether his father is safe in jail. Such public airing of fear and trauma becomes a magnet for sympathy and solidarity."Not knowing whether your father is safe, injured or even alive is a form of psychological torture," he had said in written remarks.However, Imran Khan's sister was eventually allowed to meet the former prime minister. After the visit, she said, "Imran Khan’s health is perfectly fine. However, he told me they are subjecting him to mental torture, and that Asim Munir is responsible for all of this."For the military leadership under Asim Munir, the calculus is not just about brute strength, it is about legitimacy. Pakistan’s power dynamics have long relied on a veneer of neutrality: the idea that the army guards the system while politics handles politics. Overplaying that role risks shattering the illusion.From Ayub Khan and Yahya Khan to Zia-ul-Haq and Pervez Musharraf , every era of military rule reinforced the pattern: the army positioned itself not merely as a defender of borders, but as the ultimate arbiter of Pakistan's politics and identity.Each takeover was justified through narratives of chaos, corruption, or national security, allowing the establishment to retain dominance even during civilian periods. Today, under Asim Munir, this pattern continues in a more sophisticated form: instead of overt coups, power is exercised through constitutional engineering, judicial pressure, and political sidelining, most visibly in the dismantling of Imran Khan’s political career. The military’s quest is not only to command the state but to remain indispensable to its very definition.As long as Imran Khan remains a contested figure, not just legally, but symbolically, the army's claim to neutrality becomes harder to maintain.International pressure, media scrutiny, and internal dissent all rise with every heavy-handed move.Hence, the challenge for Munir may be deeper than suppressing one man, it is about managing optics, institutional trust and political fallout.
Article Summary: Is Imran Khan still a threat to Asim Munir? The question looms over Pakistan ’s power structure. Khan has transformed from a jailed political leader into a symbolic and political counterweight to Munir’s expanding military-political dominance.

Article Title: Ghaziabad Jeweller Murder: Killed in 60 seconds, Ghaziabad jeweller stabbed to death during robbery; accused watched 25 YouTube ‘heist tutorials’
Article Text: GHAZIABAD: A 75-year-old jewellery shop owner in Modinagar was stabbed to death on Thursday morning during a robbery in Govindpuri. CCTV footage, retrieved by police, shows the victim seated at the counter when a man wearing a monkey cap enters, throws red chilli powder in his face, then climbs onto the counter and stabs him more than 10 times. The assailant was caught by local residents after a brief chase, about 30 metres from the shop, and later detained by police.The incident occurred shortly after 8.30 am, when the victim, Girdhari Lal, had opened his shop, Girdhari Lal & Sons Jewellery, on the ground floor of his residence. Locals said Lal, a long-time resident of Govindpuri colony, typically opened his store earlier than others in the area, a routine the assailant, Ankit Gupta, allegedly knew.A bike taxi rider living in the same area until his family relocated a month ago, Gupta was allegedly under financial stress after losing around Rs 20 lakh in shares and online gaming, police said. He knew that Lal owned three other jewellery shops and was well off. For a week, he recced Lal's Govindpuri shop and timed his attack to coincide with the early opening hours to take advantage of the lack of customers and other shopkeepers in the vicinity, police said.On Thursday, the accused entered the shop just after Lal began his day. He threw a fistful of red chilli powder into Lal's face. And even before Lal could react, Gupta climbed onto the shop's counter and slashed and stabbed him repeatedly with a knife, leaving him dead within seconds.Lal's son, Rupendra Soni, heard his father's screams and rushed into the shop, and tried to restrain the attacker. Soni hurled the assailant on a bench, but Soni pulled out what appeared to be a gun—a later investigation revealed it was a toy—and managed to give him a slip.As Soni chased him, local shopkeepers, responding to the commotion, captured the assailant roughly 25-30 metres from the shop. He was beaten by the crowd before being handed over to the police.The entire assault that lasted fewer than 60 seconds was captured in a CCTV camera installed in the shop. Police said they were analysing CCTV footage and gathering witness accounts to reconstruct the events in full.ACP Modinagar Amit Saxena said preliminary investigations indicated that Gupta targeted Lal's shop with the intention to steal jewellery. "He had planned the robbery around a week in advance. After attacking Lal, he had planned to grab the jewellery on display in a bag that he was carrying. It seems he hadn't anticipated that Soni or anyone would arrive so quickly," the officer said, adding that a toy gun had been recovered from Gupta.DCP (Rural) Surendra Nath Tiwari said Gupta has been detained and is being questioned. While no FIR was lodged till the filing of the report, police said the process of registering one was on.Police said the accused had bought the knife online and received it only on Wednesday. In the five days leading up to the crime, Gupta allegedly watched more than 25 heist videos on YouTube to prepare for the robbery, cops added. He also claimed to own a YouTube channel, Desire Telefilms, that has 6,25,000 subscribers.The attack sparked outrage among local residents and shopkeepers, many of whom shut down shops in protest, accusing the police of failing to maintain law and order. Sudheer Singh, a local shopkeeper, said, "The police chowki is just 200m away, yet patrolling is rare. A robbery attempt at Lal's shop happened two years ago, and the culprits were never caught. Even recent thefts in nearby shops are unresolved."DCP Tiwari assured the community that additional police forces had been deployed and that security measures in the area would be reviewed. He confirmed that a dedicated team would remain stationed in the market to prevent future incidents and increase patrolling in the area.
Article Summary: A 75-year-old jewellery shop owner was stabbed to death on Thursday morning during a robbery in Govindpuri. CCTV footage shows the victim seated at the counter when a man wearing a monkey cap enters, throws red chilli powder in his face, then climbs onto the counter and stabs him more than 10 times. The assailant was caught by local residents after a brief chase, about 30 metres from the shop, and later detained by police.

Article Title: India’s most-wanted maoist Kabir surrenders with his core squad in Madhya Pradesh
Article Text:
’Naxal-Maoist Terror Nearly Wiped Out Across India’: PM Modi Hails Police, CRPF, BSF

BHOPAL: In a major breakthrough for Madhya Pradesh’s anti-Naxal campaign, 10 Maoists of the Kanha–Bhoramdeo (KB) division — including most-wanted commander Surendar alias Kabir, who carries a Rs 77-lakh bounty — surrendered before security forces in Balaghat late Saturday night after covert negotiations facilitated by the Special Intelligence Unit (SIU) of the Hawk Force. The surrender was formalised at the official bungalow of the Inspector General (IG), Balaghat Range, after the rebels made first contact through a forest guard whom they trusted.Sources said the Maoists had initially planned to surrender in Chhattisgarh due to trust issues with Madhya Pradesh authorities, but following multiple rounds of backchannel communication and assurances from Hawk Force’s SIU, they agreed to lay down arms in Balaghat. The group arrived in two batches and surrendered under heavy security, handing over automatic weapons, rifles, grenades and detonators.Those who surrendered were identified as Surendar alias Kabir (Secretary of the Special MMC Zone) with an AK-47 rifle and 100 rounds; Rakesh Hodi, his close associate, with an AK-47 and 37 rounds; Lalsingh with an INSAS rifle and 40 rounds; Shilpa; Naveen; and Jayshila with SLR and 22 rounds; Vikram with a rifle and 7 rounds; Zarina with a rifle and 10 rounds; and Samar with detonators and 05 units.Police said this is one of the most significant surrenders ever recorded in the Kanha–Bhoramdeo zone, and with this development, Mandla district is now being considered effectively free of Maoist presence.Officials said the Maoists capitulated under the cumulative pressure of intensified search and domination operations launched after Hawk Force Inspector Ashish Sharma’s martyrdom on Wednesday. Sharma, 32, a decorated officer with two gallantry medals and an out-of-turn promotion, was killed in an encounter near Bor Talab at the sensitive tri-junction of MP, Maharashtra and Chhattisgarh. His death triggered an all-front coordinated response by Hawk Force, MP Police, Maharashtra’s commandos and Chhattisgarh Police, steadily shrinking operational space for the KB division.The 10 cadres will now participate in a state-level formal surrender programme, during which they will publicly lay down arms before Chief Minister Dr Mohan Yadav in Balaghat, marking a rare high-value ceremonial surrender under the state’s 2023 Naxal Surrender and Rehabilitation Policy. The surrendered weapons — including AK-47s, INSAS, SLR rifles, ammunition, improvised explosive materials and communication devices — have been seized for forensic and intelligence mapping.The development also reflects widening cracks within Maoist ranks. It comes weeks after the surrender of 23-year-old ACM-level cadre Sunita, member of the personal guard unit of CCM Ramder, who gave herself up at the Chauriya Hawk Force camp on October 31. Officials said her intelligence inputs suggested that several senior Maoist leaders in the Maad–Indravati–Darrekasa sector had already deserted or surrendered, triggering uncertainty and mistrust among remaining cadres.Security forces have now intensified presence across Lanji, Kirnapur, Baihar and adjoining forest belts touching Gadchiroli and Bijapur, anticipating further surrenders as operational dominance increases. Intelligence officials say the capture of Kabir, Hodi and other key KB division operatives marks a decisive shift in the anti-Naxal grid, and the Mandla–Balaghat belt may soon witness one of its most peaceful phases in decades.
Article Summary: 10 Maoists of the Kanha–Bhoramdeo (KB) division surrendered before security forces in Balaghat late Saturday night. Most-wanted commander Surendar alias Kabir, who carries a Rs 77-lakh bounty, was among them. The surrender was formalised at the official bungalow of the Inspector General (IG), Balag Hat Range.

Article Title: Karnataka shocker: Congress worker killed in Chikkamagaluru group clash; probe underway
Article Text: CHIKKAMAGALURU: Congress workers held a flash protest here Saturday following the murder of party worker and panchayat member Ganesh Gowda.Gowda, 38, was hacked to death on Kalmaradi Mutt Road while he was travelling alone in a car late Friday. Police have detained four accused. Two of them, Mithun and Sanjay, have been hospitalised with injuries, SP Vikram Amathe said, adding that four teams were trying to crack the case.According to sources, before the murder, a clash had erupted between Gowda and a few others over the removal of a banner erected on the occasion of Datta Jayanti.
